course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Engineering Optics
course.description: An introductory course in optics covering fundamentals of geometrical and physical optics. Topics include: review of geometrical optics, first order optical system and analysis, aberration, aperture and field stops; Basic wave theory, diffraction, interference, polarization, dispersion; fundamentals of optical instrumentation.

reviews.title: Engineering Optics
reviews.comment_content:
Since there is no one to give comment about this course here, thus I give some details about this course for your reference.

This course is classified into two parts, Geometric Optics (Treat light as ray) and Physical Optics (Treat light as wave).

Part I: Geometric Optics
--------------------------------------------------
1. Introduction
2. Huygens' and Fermat's Principles
3. Geometrical Optics
4. Lenses, mirrors and refractive surfaces
5. Thin, thick lenses and cardinal points in paraxial optics
6. Cardinal planes / Points in paraxial optics
7. Optical Systems - Human eyes
8. Optical Systems - Magnifier, Microscope,Telescope and Camera
9. Matrix methods in paraxial optics
10. Aberrations and optical systems

Part II: Physical Optics
--------------------------------------------------
11. Physical Optics: Making waves
12. Propagation of waves and EM waves
13. Reflection and Transmission: Fresnel Equations
14. EM waves: Multi-sources interference
15. EM waves: More two source interference
16. Diffraction
17. Fraunhofer Diffraction: General Aperture

Reference books
[1] Optics - Eugene Hecht
[2] Introduction to Matrix Methods in Optics - A. Gerrard, J.M. Burch

Lab content
--------------------------------------------------
[1] Measuring the Focal Lengths of Positive Thin Lenses and Eyepiece
[2] Assembling a Slide Projector and a Telescope
[3] Assembling a Microscope and Erect Telescope
[4] Light is a Wave, Light is an Electromagnetic Wave
[5] Newton's Ring and Michelson Interferometer
[6] Fraunhofer Diffraction of Single Slit and Grating, Reflective Grating Spectrometer

reviews.comment_teaching:
There are two lectures per week, but it emphasizes a lot on self-learning. One of the weekly lectures is always pre-recorded, as the professor hopes for us to make better use of our time to watch the videos on our own. Essentially, there is only one real-time lecture each week.

Professor Qu is a good professor explaining the concepts well. Most of the content stem from high/secondary physics. If you are familiar in optics, you will have little to no difficulty in understanding its content. It's also one of the few courses that do not involve a lot of calculus.

Things become crappy when it comes to examinations, however. Similar to other engineering courses, you need to set up a 360-no-scope camera capturing your upper body, your paper and your computer screen. Nice! What's more, you'll be awarded bonus points if you use a handwritten cheat sheet. Honestly speaking, I don't see the significance in such restrictions as well as the merits of using a handwritten but not typed cheat sheet. I'd feel less stressful in a face-to-face exam compared with an online one.
reviews.comment_grading:
Labs (x5): 15%
Homework (x6): 15% (counts the best 5 out of 6 homework towards final grade)
Midterm Examination: 20%
Final Examination: 50%

Now, the main reason I gave this section a C is because the weighing of the homework is extremely misleading. While there are 6 pieces of "homework" in total, each piece is also further separated into two assignments, with each assignment released one week after the another. Homework 5 is the only exception with an extra section C asking you to write a 400-word summary of Newton's rings, meaning there are actually 13 pieces of homework in total.
reviews.comment_workload:
As said in the grading section, the weighing for the homework can be very confusing unless you have actually taken the course. On average, each assignment (not going to use the term homework, refer to the grading section for more details) consists of 5 questions, so you should have adequate time to complete each of them.

Since the course is conducted online, there will be no hands-on labs this semester. Instead, video recordings are provided for each experiment, along with a supplementary datafile containing the values you need to calculate the result. Lab reports were written by students individually, not group. Because of this, it is not necessary to attend any lab sections according to the schedule as long as you submit the report within the deadline, i.e. 1 week.

While the workload is manageable, you have to always pay attention to any updates on its Canvas page, causing unneeded tension from my perspective. Submissions are usually opened just 3 days before its deadline rather than at the time of its release, so it's easy to miss it even if you already completed the assignments. For me, I missed two pieces of homework assignments because I forgot to hand it in.
